intro: Lucinaea acutifolia, commonly known as sharp-leaved woodruff, is a perennial herb native to the temperate regions of Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family, which includes over 13,000 species of flowering plants. The plant is characterized by its slender stems and small, lance-shaped leaves that are typically covered in fine hairs. Its fragrant, white flowers bloom in clusters during the spring and early summer. Lucinaea acutifolia is often found in moist woodlands and along stream banks, where it thrives in partial shade and well-drained soil.
